Imagine
a world where the ser blue oceans team
of life are transforming into acidic
corrosive cauldrons endangering not only
the creatures that call them home but
also the delicate balance of our
planet's ecosystems.
Today we dive deep into the hidden
crisis beneath the waves illuminate that
has the power to reshape our future.
The ocean is vital to human survival,
but human activities have been causing
harm to it. Increased human activity has
resulted in a tremendous amount of
carbon dioxide being released into the
atmosphere.
And the ocean as one of the world's
largest carbon sinks will absorb carbon
dioxide from the atmosphere and
contribute to the issue of ocean
acidification.
As of now, the average pH of the world's
ocean has reportedly dropped from 8.2 to
8.1. While you might think that a 0.1 pH
difference is more, it actually
corresponds to a 30% increase in
acidity.
Scientists project that by the end of
this century, surface ocean waters could
be 150% more acidic than they have been
since the industrial revolution.
Ocean acidification is especially
dangerous for marine calcifiers because
these creatures consume carbonate ions
to build up their shells.
However, the reaction between the
absorbed carbon dioxide and water
molecules will release hydrogen ions
that compete with shells for carbon.
Therefore, these scratches will need to
spend more energy building their shells,
causing them to have less energy
fighting food and making them harder to
grow and reproduce in smaller size. The
fish that die on them will not have
enough to eat and will have a harder
time surviving, which will eventually
indirectly affect the human food web.
So what can be done to tackle ocean
acidification to deal with the diss of
carbon dioxide in the sea water? One
possible solution is seaweed farming.
Seaweed is a multifactor resource that
offers a wide range of benefits is
gaining more interest as a solution due
to it fast growth rate and low input
requirements. They do not take up any
space on lands that are delimited and
require no fresh water, no fertilizer
and no feed. The farming is relatively
easy starting with the farmer releasing
the spores into a car for them to
develop into young seaweed plants in 30
to 60 days. During which the seaweed
will attach to the rocks or nets
provided by the farmer. Once the young
seaweed plants have reached a suitable
size, they can be transported to the
ocean over a period of 3 to 6 months.
The sew grows on these rocks and can be
harvested when reaching an appropriate
size. A group of scientists from China
has proven seed farming to be effective
in buffering acidity with sacrina
chaponica showing the highest pH
increasing ability of up to 0.1.
This is possible because seaweeds absorb
carbon dioxide during photosynthesis and
incorporate the carbon into their
tissues. The carbon is locked out when
the seaweed dies and sinks to the ocean
floor. Thereby reducing carbon dioxide
levels in the water. Seaweed farming
could be implemented in Malaysia as it
tropical climate of warm waters is
suitable for many seaweed species.
Also, Malaysia's nutrient-rich coastal
water is beneficial for seaweed growth.
In addition, Malaysia has a diverse
coastline with different types of
coastal environments providing various
options for seaweed farming sites.
Seaweed other than mitigating ocean
acidification can also be a nutritious
and sustainable food source. Provides
shelter and feeding grounds for marine
life. creates economic opportunities for
coastal communities and can even be used
for bio energy production. While seaw
farming offers several benefits for
mitigating ocean acidification, it also
has limitations and challenges. The main
limitation of seaweed farming are its
localized impact, building and
maintaining markets for sweet products
and resource allocation. In summary,
seaweed farming is a sustainable and
environmentally responsible practice
